an10.54:4.1: “Mendicants, if a mendicant isn’t skilled in the ways of another’s mind, then they should train themselves: ‘I will be skilled in the ways of my own mind.’
an10.54:5.1: And how is a mendicant skilled in the ways of their own mind?
an10.54:5.2: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they examine their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they see any dirt or blemish there, they’d try to remove it.
an10.54:5.3: But if they don’t see any dirt or blemish there, they’re happy with that, as they’ve got what they wished for:
an10.54:5.5: In the same way, reviewing is very helpful for a mendicant’s wholesome qualities.
an10.54:5.6: ‘Do I have internal serenity of heart or not? Do I have the higher wisdom of discernment of principles or not?’
an10.54:6.1: Suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows this:
an10.54:6.2: ‘I have serenity but not discernment.’ Grounded on serenity, they should practice meditation to get discernment.
an10.54:6.3: After some time they have both serenity and discernment.
an10.54:7.1: But suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows this:
an10.54:7.2: ‘I have discernment but not serenity.’ Grounded on discernment, they should practice meditation to get serenity.
an10.54:7.3: After some time they have both serenity and discernment.
an10.54:8.1: But suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows this:
an10.54:8.2: ‘I have neither serenity nor discernment.’ In order to get those wholesome qualities, they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an10.54:8.3: Suppose your clothes or head was on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an10.54:8.5: In the same way, in order to get those wholesome qualities, that person should apply outstanding enthusiasm …
an10.54:8.6: After some time they have both serenity and discernment.
an10.54:9.1: But suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows this:
an10.54:9.2: ‘I have both serenity and discernment.’ Grounded on those wholesome qualities, they should practice meditation further to end the defilements.
